predicate.note: Frames file for 'trim' based on sentences in financial subcorpus. Verbnet entries fill-9.8 wipe_manner-10.4.1, other framed members include bind, cover, face, ring; wash. These aren't the senses I expect in WSJ, though. Comparison to 'cut'.

example.name: all args
example.text: John trimmed the fat from the the expensive cut of beef with a chainsaw.
example.arg: from the the expensive cut of beef

example.name: without instrument, inverted order
example.text: John trimmed the expensive cut of beef of fat.

example.name: transitive
example.text: Earlier staff-reduction moves have trimmed about 300 jobs, the spokesman said.

example.name: with extent
example.text: This cushion could come in handy if [GM]-1 has *trace*-1 to trim fourth-quarter North American production schedules more than the already scheduled 9.5%.

example.name: start and end points
example.text: But Smith Barney's Mr. Doyle, who *trace* yesterday trimmed his 1990 Anheuser earnings projection to $2.95 a share from $3.10, called the market's reaction ``justified.''

example.name: 'tis the season
example.text: John trimmed his Christmas tree with dirty socks.

example.name: reduce
example.text: Will other workers feel like perhaps their compensation packages [their wages]-2 are going *-1 to be perhaps either trimmed *-2 down or worse as they allude to *?* in this document?
